title: Shocking moment man casually walks out of his Arkansas trial as the jury deliberates
text:
This is the shocking moment a suspect casually gets up and walks out of his Arkansas trial as the jury deliberates, before making a run for it outside court.

Surveillance footage shows Joey Watts, 37, who was being held on charges of aggravated assault and felony possession of a firearm, as he leaves Grant County Courthouse on Monday.

In the clip Watts, who had been accused of threatening a woman using a shotgun in November 2018, can be seen sitting next to his attorney before looking around the court.

Seeing an opportunity to flee he calmly stands up and walks towards the back of the room.

Joey Watts was being held on charges of aggravated assault and felony possession of a firearm

Surveillance footage shows Joey Watts, 37, looking round the Grant County Courthouse. In the clip Watts, who had been accused of threatening a woman using a shotgun in November 2018, can be seen sitting next to his attorney before looking around the court

Seeing an opportunity to flee he calmly stands up and walks towards the back of the room

Others appear to watch as he makes his way out of the court but he is not followed by anyone.

Watts then makes his way down the hall at walking pace, even appearing to stop to say something to a relative before continuing his bid for freedom.

In the final frame Watts can be seen making a break for it, running across the court car park and fleeing.

Stephen Shirron, chief deputy prosecutor for the county, told Arkansas Online: 'It's a fairly unique circumstance. One I haven't dealt with before.'

Watts was said to have been found by law enforcement less than 24 hours later.

By then he had been found guilty by the jury and sentenced to 36 years in prison.

Watts then makes his way down the hall at walking pace, even appearing to stop to say something to a relative before continuing his bid for freedom

He continues to calmly make his bid for freedom, walking down the courthouse stairs

Chief deputy prosecutor for the county said Watts' escape was 'a fairly unique circumstance'

In the final frame Watts can be seen making a break for it, running across the court car park

Grant County Sheriff's Office Chief Deputy Pete Roberts told Fox 16 the fact he was out on bond meant Watts was able to walk around.

The court does not yet have a second bailiff.

He said: 'Mainly the fact that he was not in custody, and he was not an inmate, that gave him the freedom to move around throughout the courthouse and things like that.'

Roberts added: 'The circuit court is in the process of hiring a new bailiff to prevent that, but they haven't had that done yet.'

Three people accused of helping him in his escape are now facing a class-c felony charges, Roberts said.

Watts will be back in court later this week to face charges of failure to appear after he was taken back into custody in Grant County.
